title: Victoria's Deputy Speaker also resigns, following Languiller to the backbench - 9news.com.au
text:
Victoria's Deputy Speaker also resigns, following Languiller to the backbench By Rebecca Resuta Telmo Languiller (left) and Don Nardella have resigned from the positions of Speaker and Deputy Speaker, respectively. 
Victoria's Deputy Speaker Don Nardella has announced he will resign from the position, mirroring an earlier announcement by Speaker Telmo Languiller. 
It was revealed this week both MPs had claimed the same parliamentary perk, which entitles them to collect an allowance of tens of thousands of dollars if they live more than 80km from Melbourne's CBD and maintain a second residence in the city. 
Premier Daniel Andrews today said their resignations were "the right decision". 
Mr Nardella released a statement this afternoon saying he had "acted in accordance with all rules regarding Member of Parliament allowances" but that his "first priority" had always been the people of his electorate of Melton and as a result he would be withdrawing from the position of Deputy Speaker. 
He had claimed the second residence allowance for living in Ocean Grove on the Bellarine Peninsula since April 2014. The beachside town is 98km from Melbourne, while Melton is only 50km from the CBD. 
Mr Languiller on Thursday said he would repay more than $37,000 he claimed from the public purse before today releasing a statement saying that was "not enough". 
He had claimed the second residence allowance for living in the upmarket seaside town of Queenscliff despite his electorate of Tarneit being just 30km from the city. 
He lived in the rental home on the Bellarine Peninsula, about 100km from Melbourne, for most of 2016. He now lives primarily in Footscray, which is also outside his electorate. 
"No matter what difficult personal circumstances I may have been going through, I have to recognise it as an error of judgement and I accept that I should pay the price for that error of judgement," he wrote. 
He also thanked Premier Daniel Andrews for his support over the last two years as he faced family challenges. 
"I regret that this issue, if not addressed, could damage the position of Speaker and the Labor Party that I love," he added. 
Both MPs will return to the backbench. Candidates to replace the roles of Speaker and Deputy Speaker will be nominated at the next caucus meeting. 
With AAP.
